name: Andrew Farrow
text: It is a beautiful building, but certainly not what one would expect. It is very tranquil Japanese style of architecture. When you first walk in you are greeted by a macaw and an African grey parrot and extremely friendly staff. The at they have is very nice and a lot of revolutionary America style themes pieces of art. I was really looking forward to seeing the civil war exhibits they have advertised on their website but the only one that was on display was a bust of Robert E. Lee. Definitely a neat little place to check out of you have time.

name: Amanda Paine
text: I enjoyed the artwork and the grounds, but the cages the macaw and African Grey were in were depressing. No toys. No variety in the perch sizes. No mirrors. They were really too small for birds that size. Bama seems to have pulled out all his tail feathers to have something to do. The cages and the floor around them were also filthy. The birds are clearly not as important as the beautiful grass that surrounds the buildings. That was clear to me.

name: Susan Bhaggan
text: Beautiful Americana art work.  Sophisticated and housed in a lovely pagoda style building surrounded by manicured Japanese gardens. A must visit gem in Tuscaloosa.

name: Christine Grenig
text: We visited back on Labor Day weekend.  The museum had beautiful art work and very friendly staff.  My daughter is an art history major at UA and she would love to explore working there during her time in Tuscaloosa.

name: John Goodwin
text: It's in the Westervelt building off Jack Warner parkway, not the best location. Very small very limited, quite unimpressive . You'd think the sheer presence of the U of A would generate a better facility but then again 'here? Football is after all king.

name: Chris Turner
text: My Wife and I really enjoyed it. It has some beautiful pieces of early American Art.

name: Melissa Tuten
text: We used this a meeting place for a staff day apart and got your of the museum. Beautiful art and very knowledgeable staff.

name: The Amateur Wizard
text: Most of the place is closed off unless you call in advance. Though the collection is fascinating, it’s not enough to be satisfied with and there’s no organization. At least it’s free.

name: pandacey
text: I love the Japanese culture there

name: Amanda
text: Interesting and beautiful artwork.

name: Sonja Doss
text: Homework assignment.

name: Vanessa
text: Nice

name: Julie Flynn
text: Must see.

name: Jason Shafer
text: Wonder place .great for events .nice to see some history preserved for future generations

name: Gottfried Kibelka
text: Event space is well thought out and comes with a nicely sized kitchen. Give them a call and take a look, you will like it. Museum is smallish and needs some more technical explanations to make it more engaging.

name: Nicholas Blackstock
text:
This place gets 5 stars because there are no apparent downsides that I've ever noticed. Easy to find, just a few minutes of hwy 280.

Truthfully speaking, I've never been inside the larger museum room and am not exactly sure what all it entails. This review is specific to this building being used as a party/event venue. I've been on 3 separate occasions now (2 holiday parties and a baby shower) and have always had a good time. You can setup the room however you'd like with tables, chairs, microphone, speakers etc. There's also kitchen space and easily accessible restrooms to take advantage of.

On this same side of the building where parties can be hosted, there's also a little bit of interactive museum stuff... fun!! Some cool pictures and historical information displays can be found throughout this room as well! Brick walls, high open ceilings and all the rustic decor makes this place feel unique, authentic and like any other event venue that you'll find in Birmingham (that I know of).

name: Belinda Doneff
text: The food was awesome. When I come back down  here. I will definitely  stop to eat.

name: Rosa Hill
text: Great history about our water system.

name: Paul Rogers
text: This is a cool historical venue and event space that includes an informative museum about the history of the water works and Birmingham's water resources.

name: Carol Caffee
text: Wonderful history with wall displays and great venue for a party!

name: roger hicks
text: Very clean

name: Kristine Sizemore Sandler Training in Alabama
text: Great event space

name: C Way
text: Amazing. Wonderful place.

name: Sidney Skanes
text: Really didn't see much. Worked on bridge

name: Team Mountain
text: Not sure about it as a museum, for touring, but it’s a GREAT meeting location.

name: Bill Jenkins
text: Very nice place.

name: Burr Battle
text: Nice staff and look

name: oliver brown (ollie)
text: great place to have a reception

name: Charly Hanson
text: This is a diamond in the ruff on the history of Birmingham water works.

name: Arron Trejo
text: Amazing

name: Angelia Renda
text: Great

name: Stephanie Phillips
text: Lovely little museum.  Worth the trip if you live and hour or more away if you want to see the current exhibition.  Worth going more often if you live close by.  Not a big show going on when we went, only one room really.

name: Rozella Rasco
text: Love this place!!!

name: Sharon Clayton
text: A lovely museum. They have had some very nice special exhibits.

name: Julie Bateman
text: Interesting art with wonderful imaginings.

name: Eric Stafford
text: Great little art museum.

name: Andrew Van Winkle
text: A great place for the finer things

name: Cheryl Martin
text: Such generosity.  The museum is an opportunity right up there with any major museum without traveling to New York.  As bereavement coordinator for a hospice I personally paid the fee to have a memorial service here for the bereaved.  Mr. And mrs. Burrows left a wonderful legacy.  The day we had the service the WPA collection from the Smithsonian Institute was also on loan to the Burrows Museum.

name: heather Murray
text: Great art musuem

name: Zacc Gleason
text: Great place to view art/Pottery

name: Edward Mulder
text: Nice for being as small as it is. Not much to elaborate on really.

name: Tia Hogan
text: I loved the fact my son enjoyed it and he wants to go back next year

resp.text: Wonderful! We are always happy to hear from visitors to the TVMA - but YOUNG visitors especially hold a place in our hearts. We can't wait to see you again!!

name: Sara Pack
text: Don't be like me and neglect going to this great local museum of art for far too long! Go often. There's a free afternoon every week, but it's worth the fee to practically have the place to yourself on a slow day. I was blessed with the opportunity to see the members collection this year (2019).

resp.text: Sara, thank you so much for your review! We're delighted you came by to see the exhibit - we'll hope to see you back for Spruce Pine Pottery this autumn!

name: George Lair
text: Dick Cooper's exhibit of picture taken at Muscle Shoals Sound Studios was fantastic. I'm always impressed with the exhibits featured at the museum.

resp.text: Thank you so much! We had a great time getting a look at some local music history!!

name: FBF Family
text: Beautiful pieces and well displayed.

name: Nicole Hughes
text:
I've often wondered about this jewel hidden in the Heart of Dixie. I've passed it by one million times over it seems and I've yet to enter. It's still a mystery that is only a stone's throw away from my home.
I'm an artistic person by nature (even if I'm not very good at it) and Therein lies the mystery. I live and love everything art. Books, paintings, sculptures, nature itself and probably the most heaping helping of music you can imagine. I don't ever hardly watch television. I don't have cable, satellite, etc  And I don't want to. I never watch. If I do sit down and watch a movie I rarely get quiet enough to get it all in. I've only recently got Netflix on my phone as a gift from a concerned friend who thought I should get a Dr exam and thourogh check-up since I don't know which Kardashian is which or why it is important. LOL as we all say and I'm on a mission to enter this place this coming week and I will solve this mystery and make sure that you are super informed.
I'm excited.

resp.text: We're so glad to hear from you! We're open Monday-Friday 9-5, and (during exhibits) you can catch us Sundays 1-3. Come by and say hello - we'd love to show you around!

name: Allen Parsons
text: Okay, maybe not the greatest museum on the planet, but give the plucky institution credit for spirit and enhancing the cultural richness of the Shoals. The rotating exhibits support Southern arts. The permanent petroglyph exhibit of prehistorically carved stone reminds the viewer of a long-ago world. Give it 20 to 30 minutes and you've more than covered its offerings. Helen Keller birth place is a chip shot away.

name: LJ Pack
text: Nice local art museum

resp.text: Thank you! We hope you enjoyed the Spruce Pine Pottery exhibit. We hope you'll stop by to check out our next exhibit - a three-days-only survey of Dick Cooper's photography, Nov. 14th-16th!!

name: Sybil Viator
text: Great service and a very special place!
